arm_group.description: nutrition and hygiene education by community health workers

brief_summary.textblock:
This study will determine if an education program about hygiene and child feeding practices,
      taught by local village community health workers, will improve child growth and decrease the
      prevalence of childhood malnutrition in a rural region of Kenya.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Nutrition/Hygiene Education Program for the Prevention of Child Malnutrition in Rural Kenya

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Child of a mother living in the catchment area of the study who delivered during the
             enrollment period

intervention.description: Monthly education sessions about child feeding and hygiene for mothers of young children, conducted by local Kenyan community health workers

clinical_study.official_title: A Nutrition/Hygiene Education Program for the Prevention of Child Malnutrition in Rural Kenya

other_outcome.time_frame: Prevalence assessed when children reach 24 months of age

primary_outcome.description: Child malnutrition rates, as measured by the prevalence of underweight, wasting, and growth stunting of the children in each group
primary_outcome.time_frame: Measured when children are 24 months of age

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

results_reference.citation: Black RE, Allen LH, Bhutta ZA, Caulfield LE, de Onis M, Ezzati M, Mathers C, Rivera J; Maternal and Child Undernutrition Study Group. Maternal and child undernutrition: global and regional exposures and health consequences. Lancet. 2008 Jan 19;371(9608):243-60. Review.

Bhutta ZA, Ahmed T, Black RE, Cousens S, Dewey K, Giugliani E, Haider BA, Kirkwood B, Morris SS, Sachdev HP, Shekar M; Maternal and Child Undernutrition Study Group. What works? Interventions for maternal and child undernutrition and survival. Lancet. 2008 Feb 2;371(9610):417-40. Review.
Dewey KG, Adu-Afarwuah S. Systematic review of the efficacy and effectiveness of complementary feeding interventions in developing countries. Matern Child Nutr. 2008 Apr;4 Suppl 1:24-85. Review.

secondary_outcome.description: Child growth as measured by change in z score of the children in each group
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured when children are 24 months of age

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Prevention
